title: Player Held Hostage in Game for Over 4 Hours
body:
https://www.reddit.com/r/leagueoflegends/comments/7n08zw/how_should_i_deal_with_being_held_hostage_in_a/

Two Duos that were communicating with each other got into a game on opposite teams. One of the duos were playing {{champion:8}} and {{champion:18}} and the Other were playing {{champion:75}} and {{champion:45}} . All of these champs had some form of infinite scaling on them. {{champion:75}} and {{champion:45}} on their q's, {{champion:8}} had Grasp to stack health, and {{champion:18}} had dark harvest. The fact that they were duo's allowed them to prevent either team from surrendering. Since both duo's had inf scaling and the rest of the players didn't, this allowed them to take control of the game and prevent anyone progressing. By the 1.5 hour mark 5/6 non premades had quit. The {{champion:12}} who made the reddit post stuck out the entirety of the game because he was afraid of being punished for leaving a game. The fact that this game doesn't have some form of protection like this yet is just sad.

**Edit:** 
I just read through all of the comments as of 1/1/18 and I'm going to answer some questions that some people had.
*The point of this thread was that there is no form of leaver protection yet, not that there isn't anything preventing friends from playing on opposite teams.

*By the time the other 6 people had realized what was going on, it was too late and their stats couldn't compete with infinitely stacking abilities.

*While yes it does feel like a one in a million chance of happening, this has been gaining more attention, hell it has 25k upvotes on the reddit post last time I checked. It might get even more common. So my question for you is, would you still have the same mentality if this happened in one of your ranked games?

replies.body: This really feels like once in a million chance of happening. Punish them accordingly, you don't need to create a whole new standard for it.
It feels like it but it happened more than once..
Alright, maybe twice. Three time possible. Hell, even 100. That's still an extremely small percentage of the playerbase.

but only a small percentage tries this.
That's the point, this shouldn't work if you try it. It's not a coincidence.
The 2 duo's actively try this, and succeed.
How can they try it if they are on opposite teams. And it's very unlikely for them to go against each other.

They could check their mmr and play so that they're really close to each other, then queue up at the same time.  If they get an "accept" at the same time join and then if they aren't opponents, dodge.  Repeat until getting this situation and make up for the time wasted by wasting another 4+ hours.

It's "unlikely" to happen randomly, but if you work for it you could probably make it happen fairly quickly.

They also probably queue at unconventional times when there are less players, in which case matchmaking is more lenient regarding MMR differences. Finally, they play on OCE, which is less populated, too.

So use your line of thinking and assume it happens 50 times.  That's 6 people per game who may need to file a support ticket.  So you send in 300 support tickets.  Do you really think that's an efficient use of the support ticket system?  Have you even used the support ticket system?  Crank that up to 100 games, that's 600 tickets.  This can keep going.

Again, I'm harking on your point because you're being the most stubborn.  You don't want to accept the fact that sometimes you have to make a change to prevent even just a few people from going through such a thing.  It would take longer to keep the support ticket as the official solution than it would to change the way the forfeit voting system works after a predetermined period of time.  

I don't even have to provide you a direct comparison to another software platform.  You have to realize that 1) the user experience is horrible for those involved, 2) more people WILL do this hostage-taking because human nature, and 3) this will discourage people from playing on these smaller servers, and thus be a net-negative for Riot Games as their smaller regions suffer loss of player numbers due to an issue they refuse to address (if they take your approach).  Less people playing means those that do continue playing have a higher chance of falling into this hostage situation, leading to more tickets, and leading to more bad PR and public outcry that Riot is refusing to address a situation that is horrible for those few that do get involved.  It will lead to more Reddit posts, more bad PR, more forums getting flooded, etc etc etc.  And all this crap could be fixed with one small tweak to how the surrender vote system works after 90 min or so.  Hmm, which honestly seems like a bigger waste of time?  A literal couple of lines of code or all of the above?

Sometimes, you have to fix a problem even if it only affects a statistical minority.  It's called PR.  It's called being a reasonable company.  Submitting a support ticket for issues like this takes time away from more pressing matters.  And the problem itself can literally be fixed more quickly than 1 support ticket process from beginning to end.  Seeing as how you have to deal with an automated response on your first ticket submission, then you have to have a conversation explaining to a Riot support agent, and then the support agent has to watch the replay, which in this case would be in the 3-5 hour range, depending on how far along this gets.

Stop being stubborn and realize that simply implementing a small fix is far more efficient and far better PR for Riot.

Yeah but still you cant play league for 4 hours because the game need to be finished . This is the hick in this story . Also the fact if you leave you can surely be reported . I mean the strat of never surrendering is sad . They even putted two ppl in each team so there are no surrender vote ever happening .

Actually, it really means you do need to set a standard.  Sure, it happens for a statistical minutiae, but for those who go through it, it's a nightmare.  And those who go through this risk getting a 14-day ban for leaving a game that was being held hostage.  It's a situation that is setup to severely punish the innocents while letting the guilt parties go.

And you have to remember the copycat concept - now that this has been proven to work, you will inevitably start seeing more and more people in these lower-populated regions start trying to one-up each other.  These 4 guys made a 5-hour game happen?  Better shoot for a 6-hour game.  Etc. 

The solution doesn't even have to be a difficult one to implement.  My proposal is to only require a simple majority after 1 hour 30 min.  The vast majority of games are done by this time, so this implementation would address the very problem of games being held hostage.  Sure, there are some outliers that are legitimate games that go on for 90 min or so, but most games in this time range are the result of some sort of trolling, inting, or intentionally dragging the game out.

Being a statistical minutiae doesn't mean a problem shouldn't be addressed.  Did you know most Windows security updates are fixed because they were exploited only a handful of times?  Out of billions of PCs?  Because it's true.  And the rationale is simple - if word of the exploit gets out, it's almost guaranteed to be copied over and over and over again.  Not to mention that life is made miserable for those unlucky few who suffer through said exploits - either through losing their bank account information, money, or just their documents and pictures.  Same as this games-held-hostage idea.

If major software companies took this approach to patching exploits in their systems, just imagine how quickly things would spiral out of control.  You always address a major issue before it becomes widespread.  You always quash a bug before the masses figure it out.

> And those who go through this risk getting a 14-day ban for leaving a game that was being held hostage. It's a situation that is setup to severely punish the innocents while letting the guilt parties go.

You're being really dramatic about this. If they're in good standing, leaving a game isn't going to get you a 2 week ban. If you're truly innocent, you might suffer at worse, a que timer, but my occasional left game doesn't net me a punishment. You throw a support ticket declaring what happened, and you go about your life.

> Not to mention that life is made miserable for those unlucky few who suffer through said exploits - either through losing their bank account information, money, or just their documents and pictures. Same as this games-held-hostage idea.

You're comparing actual vulnerabilities in a system to some dudes trolling. Tbh, not as bad as 9/11 dude, but you're comparing apples and oranges. This is not an exploit, it's two dudes being dicks, and they can be punished for it. This is not a major issue. This is not a bug.
Punish them accordingly? You realize most of the team had left by that point right? You can't punish if you can't see the score screen
Upvoted, and that's because I agree with your point, not just because your name is awesome.
Something that would prevent friends from playing one another? This seems like a highly unusual event.
You missed the entire point of this. A player was held hostage because they were afraid of being punished by a system when they would have done nothing wrong.

I've played thousands of games and I've never been in one longer than 1 hour and some change. Just make it so after the 90 minute mark the FF button reduces to 3 people. And at 2 hours 2 people, cause by that point it's definitely being held hostage.

I could understand that apprehension for a ranked game, but something seems amiss about this situation. How often would your discord partners appear on opposing teams? This person didn't report the players, then didn't write a support ticket.

I'm for getting these players reprimanded, but something seems off about this story.

The "how often would it happen" argument is a little weak in a game like League. The huge playerbase and its activity level mean that so many League games are played that whatever can happen _will_ happen eventually.

The real problem, maybe I just don't have enough friends.

It still sounds pretty rare: your friends would have to queue up at the same time, have similar skill level, and both groups would have to want to ruin a game. 

It's only from my personal experience. But, I think you're right, it's more likely than not to reoccur.
This happened on a much smaller server than ours (OCE) and likely at a time when there were even fewer people online, ever play at 4 am? I often get same people in my games multiple times..

I think the smaller server is more favorable for this setup than a larger one. But yes, I have played at off-peak times, where you're much more likely to be matched with players of varying skill-sets.
Right? And the original post on reddit indicates he did nothing to report these players.
He indicates that his client bugged at the "Skip Stats" screen, so he couldn't report them.

And he didn't use a support ticket, claiming they copy paste stuff.

He stayed in this game **for hours**. Why was submitting a support ticket too much of a hassle?
Riot should punish these people as an example. They could have done that in a custom game but instead took a game hostage.

Yeah... this is not that hard a problem to solve.  This is an extremely rare thing to happen.  Riot just needs to Tyler1 these players as hard as it possibly can to make a statement of "we do not tolerate this toxic bullcrap".  Find their mains, and perma them.  Bam.  Done.  The problem isn't that this kinda crap happens and we need to make some system so friends can't queue together or whatever... it's that extreme troll shit like this is hardly ever punished.

If riot took a hard stance on the most extreme trolls in the game, the game would end up with less trolls.  Funny how that works.  Perma these guys... along with that Tahm/Anivia duo that used to shut down games in bronze by repeatedly eating/walling in a member of their team for like 10 minutes to ensure a loss.  What's more, they should make a big deal about doing it.  Put up a post on the main client saying "these idiots were permabanned... don't act like these idiots".  Riot needs to police it's own players better, that's all.

My proposed solution:

Make surrender votes only require 3 Yes votes after 1 hour 30 min.  This would remain consistent with the pre-20 min votes requiring unanimous Yes votes, and would remove all power from duos to hold a game hostage for hours on end.  This also sets the upper limit of the 3 Yes votes well beyond most reasonable game times.  The vast majority of games are over by 1 hour 30 min, so the likelihood of this affecting real games is very, very low.

When making a change to fix an exploit, you have to be conservative.  90 mins is a fair cutoff point.

If it's a 6v4 then all you have to do is work with the three on the other team who are being abused. 

Work together to feed one team kills and buffs, and have them all push a lane, while the other three choose not to defend, but just clear jungle camps / split push if the duo on the 'attack' team decides to try and get stacks for their scaling by staying with their team. 

The attacking three just hit all three lanes at once, and toss in a zzrot portal as well to speed up the tower pushing. The two defenders either focus on wave  clear, which means they don't scale as hard, or they focus on scaling, which gives you a chance to push deeper into their base in one of the lanes.

End goal if to have all three inhibs down in one base, then get elder dragon and baron on the attacking team. At that point you should be able to  close out the game, or  at least get  1 or 2 nexus turrets, at  which point you repeat that process until you win. 

It's still probably going to be a game that lasts over an hour, but it would definitely be done before the 4 hour mark.

The only way this kind of abuse is possible is because people would rather quit the game than play a long game.
